description: Rice is one of the most important staple crops worldwide, primarily grown for its edible grain. It is a versatile crop that adapts to various climates and is cultivated extensively in flooded fields or paddies. Rice serves as a primary source of calories for billions of people, especially in Asia and Africa.
uses: Staple food for billions of people

soil.type: Clayey, loamy soils with good water retention

climate.watering: Rice requires consistent water supply and is often grown in flooded conditions during its growing period. Proper drainage is essential during the ripening stage to prevent diseases.

symptoms: Yellowing of leaf margins that progresses to browning and wilting.
Water-soaked lesions that enlarge and merge, causing leaf death.
Stunted plant growth and reduced grain yield.

background.cause: Bacterial infection spread through contaminated water, soil, and seeds.
background.spread_by: Irrigation water, wind, and infected plant debris.

cure: Use copper-based bactericides or streptomycin to control the disease.
Remove and destroy infected plants to limit disease spread.
diseases.fertilizers: Avoid excessive nitrogen application, which promotes lush growth and susceptibility.
prevention: Ensure proper drainage to reduce water stagnation.

symptoms: Small, circular brown spots with a gray center on leaves.
Severe infections result in leaf blighting and yellowing.
Reduced grain filling and poor-quality grains.

background.cause: A fungal disease favored by nutrient deficiencies, particularly potassium.
background.spread_by: Windborne spores, infected seeds, and plant debris.

cure: Apply fungicides like Mancozeb or Carbendazim.
Supplement potassium fertilizers to improve plant health.
diseases.fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers with potassium and silicon reduce disease severity.
prevention: Avoid water stress and maintain proper irrigation schedules.
Treat seeds with fungicides before sowing.

symptoms: Gray to whitish spots with dark margins on leaves.
Lesions on stems and nodes, leading to plant breakage.
Premature drying of leaf tips and reduced grain formation.

background.cause: A fungal disease spread by airborne spores in warm, humid conditions.

cure: Apply systemic fungicides like Tricyclazole or Carbendazim.
prevention: Ensure proper spacing for better air circulation.
Apply preventive fungicides during favorable conditions.

symptoms: Brown lesions with yellowish halos, spreading from leaf tips and margins.
Infected leaves dry out and exhibit a scorched appearance.
Reduced photosynthesis and grain yield.

background.cause: A fungal disease spread by water splash and infected plant debris.

cure: Remove infected plant debris and improve field hygiene.
diseases.fertilizers: Balanced nutrients with adequate potassium reduce susceptibility.
prevention: Maintain proper field drainage to avoid prolonged leaf wetness.

symptoms: Long, narrow, reddish-brown lesions on leaves.
Severe infections cause leaves to wither prematurely.
Reduced plant vigor and grain yield.

background.cause: A fungal disease associated with nutrient-deficient soils.

cure: Remove infected leaves and plant debris.
diseases.fertilizers: Ensure adequate potassium and nitrogen supply.
prevention: Practice crop rotation to reduce pathogen pressure.

symptoms: White streaks or scratches on leaves due to feeding.
Leaves become skeletonized, and plant growth is stunted.
Reduced tillering and grain yield.

background.cause: Insect pest infestation by larvae and adults of *Dicladispa armigera*.
background.spread_by: Movement of adult insects between fields.

cure: Apply insecticides like Chlorpyrifos or Lambda-cyhalothrin.
Manually remove adults and larvae in small infestations.
diseases.fertilizers: Balanced nutrient application improves plant recovery.
prevention: Plant early to avoid peak pest activity.
Use resistant varieties and ensure good field sanitation.

symptoms: Irregular, grayish-green or brown lesions on the leaf sheath.
Soft, rotting tissue with fungal growth at the base of plants.
Yellowing and wilting of leaves.

background.cause: A fungal disease caused by *Rhizoctonia solani*, common in poorly drained fields.

prevention: Practice crop rotation and field sanitation.

preventive_practices: Use disease-resistant rice varieties to reduce vulnerability.
Ensure proper field hygiene by removing debris and practicing crop rotation.
Monitor crops for early disease signs and take timely action.
Maintain optimal water and nutrient management.
